etymology.description: 馬(馬) (mǎ, "horse") providing the meaning of riding + 奇(奇) (qí, "strange") providing the phonetic element -> riding a horse -> to ride
etymology.interpretation: The character uses the semantic component 馬(馬) (mǎ, "horse") to indicate the act of riding a horse, combined with the phonetic component 奇(奇) (qí, "strange") to suggest the pronunciation. This combination effectively conveys the concept of riding, typically on horseback.
etymology.simplification: The traditional 騎 was simplified to 骑 by removing the 馬(馬) (mǎ, "horse") radical and replacing it with its simpler form 马(马) (mǎ, "horse"), maintaining the essential meaning and readability.

examples.chinese: 假日里我常去郊外骑马(假日裏我常去郊外騎馬)。
examples.pinyin: Jiàrì lǐ wǒ cháng qù jiāowài qí mǎ.
examples.english: I often go to the countryside to ride horses on holidays.

examples.chinese: 上班时他喜欢骑车(上班時他喜歡騎車)，感受风的速度(感受風的速度)。
examples.pinyin: Shàngbān shí tā xǐhuān qí chē, gǎnshòu fēng de sùdù.
examples.english: He likes to ride his bike to work, feeling the speed of the wind.
